body:
Save your time and frustration,from searching all over the Internet.


***This Guide is for BIOS Systems Only, not UEFI***

Boot from your Apricity OS Medium.

Open up the Terminal and follow the instuctions carefully:

1. Become Administrator
# su

2. Show all available partitions
# lsblk -f

3. Find and Mount your / System Partition   (example=sda5)
# mount /dev/sda5 /mnt

4. IF you used a SEPERATE BOOT Partition (example=sda6), MOUNT it too OR else IGNORE this step
# mount /dev/sda6 /mnt/boot

5. Make these additional mounts also:
# mount -t proc proc /mnt/proc
# mount -t sysfs sys /mnt/sys
# mount -o bind /dev /mnt/dev
# mount -t devpts pts /mnt/dev/pts/

6. Chroot Into your Installation
# chroot /mnt

7. Run Os-Prober
# os-prober

8. Install Grub into your desired drive       (Usually sda)
# grub-install /dev/sda
# grub-install --recheck /dev/sda

9. Create the new Grub configuration file
# grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg

10. Exit the Chroot
# exit

11. Done. Time To Go Home!
# reboot

## Please Use "Copy-Paste" for all of the above Commands, to avoid mistakes ##

:) (:

body:
Hello community!

Most of us, when we decide to plunge into the Linux World, we usually end up installing our Linux system along with a Windows installation (already pre-installed).
This is totally natural, as sometimes, using 2 Operating Systems is kind of mandatory (for completing our everyday tasks).
The common, Traditional scenario is this:
You already have a Windows installation, you create some free space in your hard disk drive and then you install a Linux distro, having the Linux Grub Bootloader taking over the Windows Bootloader.
This has a great disadvantage though.
If something happens to Grub or If you refresh/re-install/upgrade your Windows system (especially Windows 10 version, which overwrites itself upon previous builds) you will end up in an awkward situation.
You'll be left with a machine that carries 2 fully-operational systems, but unable to boot from one or any of them.
Then, you have to remedy this, spending precious time and energy.
What if you care more about your Linux system?
What if there was an easy way to get it back?
Well, There is.

Let's suppose this is your first time in the Linux world.
You don't know what Linux is, but you really want to try it out.
Long-time, seasoned Linux users most probably don't need this, as they usually are capable of overcoming any issue with Grub or Windows Bootloader, easily.
Still, many of you out there, might find this very handy.
Also, this way of Booting your machine, can be proven very helpful if you are Triple-Booting, since all of your Linux Systems will be using their own GRUB and configuration, independently, without interfering with each other.
I am not Triple-Booting, i have never Triple-Booted, so this is just an assumption i'm making.
If you do, and feel like trying this out, send us your feedback.

Enough said, let's start:

1. If you already have Windows installed in your pc, download and install this free software: EasyBCD http://neosmart.net/EasyBCD/
It supports Windows 10 and it's a configurable Windows bootloader.
By installing it, you won't notice any difference to your System.
It just boots your Windows (for now).

2. Create free unformatted space on your hard disk drive, for installing your ApricityOS.

3. Run ApricityOS installer, follow the easy steps and when asked for the Partitioning scheme, choose a custom configuration.
GRUB MUST be installed either on your /boot partition (if you choose to have one) or on your /system partition, according to your setup.
Do NOT install GRUB in the MBR, as this will cancel the purpose of this Tutorial.

Now, it is also a good time to create a seperate /home partition, which will carry your personal data and configurations, and will/can remain intact upon a system failure or a system re-installation.

4. Take a note of your /boot or /system Partition CAPACITY and FILESYSTEM, eg: "/system" might look like this: /dev/sda5 [Ext4 40GB]
(you will be needing this info later)

5. Finish with the rest of installation process, as you would normally do and Restart.

6. Upon Restart, you will be presented with Windows operating system only.
Don't worry, your brand new ApricityOS is there, hidden, waiting patiently for you.

7. Now, you need to create an entry and point the EasyBCD Windows bootloader to the Partition you installed GRUB before.

Run the “EasyBCD” program.
Go to:
“Add New Entry” > “Linux/BSD” > “Type” > choose GRUB2 > “Name” > ApricityOS > “Drive” > choose the Partition you took note of, when you were installing ApricityOS.
From the list you see, it is the “Linux” partition, with a capacity of “40GB” (according to my example - yours might differ)
Not NTFS partition, Not SWAP partition.
Now, save/apply your changes and exit the program.
That's pretty much it.

Upon next restart, you'll be presented with a choice of running Windows or ApricityOS (Using the EasyBCD Bootloader).
If you choose ApricityOS, EasyBCD bootloader will redirect you to GRUB.
From there onwards, it's the same as usual.

There is a downside to this.
Starting your Linux system using a chain of Bootloaders, is time-consuming.
You can edit the waiting-time of EasyBCD bootloader from the EasyBCD program in Windows, as you can also edit the time GRUB waits untill starts booting, from your Linux system.
A “2” seconds delay in both bootloaders is almost not noticeable.

I have been using this setup for over a year now, and i consider it highly advantageous compared to just having GRUB managing my systems.
Plus, for those people that are Dual-Booting, distro-hopping and want to run various linux distros in the normal way (not through Virtualization) this is the ultimate solution.

What happens if the EasyBCD bootloader fails?
As with a GRUB failure, you need to solve this issue yourselves.
Fix MBR from Windows installation media (GUI) or use their included command line tools.
Maybe even re-install Windows if needed.
It really depends on your priorities.

Treat Bootloaders nicely and they'll respect you.
They are NOT the part of your system, to be playing with.

PS: EasyBCD is an EXTREMELY powerful program.
It can turn your Dual-Booting experience into a Dream or a Nightmare.
Do NOT apply changes in the Booting Order carelessly, as they might and WILL destroy your Booting process.
Be very CAUTIOUS when DELETING a Boot Entry.
Maybe you should even avoid doing this, since you can install a new Linux distro, where your old one was, using the same configuration on the Partitioning Scheme (Very Handy) and using exactly the same configuration on the EasyBCD program (no need to change anything -that is-)
EasyBCD program is NOT “system-specific” when it comes to Linux Operating Systems.
It is only “Partition-specific”.

Enjoy!
name: [Dual-Booting / The “Other” Way]

You don’t know how or why it happened, but you’re in that same place again.
Your System is not working properly, and you’re too tired to even starting thinking of finding a way to fix it.

Would you ever take a trip with an elegant cruise ship, knowing that there are no Life-Boats on board?
Obviously No.

Starting off, you always need to create a seperate /home partition, for making things easy and convenient for you.

Backup software in Linux, exists and comes in many forms.
I will focus on the important stuff for every new-comer to Linux, and for me personally.

Backup software must be user-friendly, must include a GUI, and must be able to complete the task, requiring the less steps possible.

Here enters “Timeshift” : http://www.teejeetech.in/p/timeshift.html

It does not copy/mess with your personal files (/home), so your files remain intact upon a system restore.
Supports Backup, Restore, Browse Backup, Delete, Cloning System on another device, change settings, include-exclude files and folders and scheduling.
This is pretty much EVERYTHING one might need, from a Backup-Restore utility, which is wrapped-up in a very clean, easy-to-understand, easy-to-use graphical interface.

You can revert to an older backup, by a click of a button, or in the case that your system has been rendered unbootable, you can always fire-up your ApricityOS installation media, connect to Internet, install Timeshift while in Live-Boot Mode and Restore your Backup!

It has been mentioned that, some times, Intel-based Systems freeze randomly, for no apparent reason.
One of the causes MIGHT be that you are missing the Intel Microcode Update for your Intel CPU.
To remedy this, give:
$ sudo pacman -S intel-ucode
to install the Intel Microcode Update, and then give:
$ sudo grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg
to recreate the Grub configuration file.
$ sudo reboot
Grub adresses the issue of loading the intel-ucode.img BEFORE the initramfs-linux.img, automatically.  ;)
Hope it helps some!

Knowing that Apricity is a desktop oriented distro, wouldn't it be better to ship a kernel optimized for desktops?

I use Liquorix (https://liquorix.net/) as my main kernel and I'm having some pretty good performance. In my opinion the main difference comes from the CPU scheduler, which is the BFS (Brain Fuck Scheduler, yes, it's a pretty name hehehe), instead of the mainline CFS (Completely Fair Scheduler). The CFS works well on CPUs with 1 core to 4096 cores, while the BFS is optimized for CPUs with less than 8 cores.

Seems like it will take some time for the average desktop to have more than 8 cores for their CPUs. So I think it's a good idea to implement the BFS for now.

If you guys want more information about BFS, please check these links:
https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/linux-ck
The Scheduler creator made a white paper about it: http://ck.kolivas.org/patches/bfs/bfs-faq.txt

After several Apricity installation attempts on two computers with two different nVidia cards I have some things to share.

1. In case of installation failure use 'tab' key on initial installation window screen options.
2. Press Space on command line and write: 'nomodeset'.
3. Then you get to the decreased resolution screen installation welcome window.
4. Connect to Internet, using Set the network connection option, press Play button to establish the connection.
5. Get install Apricity OS.
6. Reboot.
7. In initial Grub screen press 'e' key on default option.
8. Scroll down using down using arrow key and then Left arrow key to get to right after 'quiet splash' and write 'nomodeset' word.
9. F10.
10. After you get to the Apricity, apparently in lower resolution display screen - get your installation updated.
11. Open the Adding/Removing software app, search 'nvidia'.
12.A. On older machines pick: nVidia-340xx, nVidia-340xx-lipgl, nvidia-340xx-utils to be installed and REMOVE the last package: xf86-video-nouveau. Press - go ahead icon.
12.B. On newer machines same as above BUT you don't have to remove the xf86.. package.

We're very excited to announce Apricity's first ever stable Release Candidate. Apricity OS 04.2016 Beta is being released alongside Apricity OS 04.2016 RC1. This month, a lot of effort has gone into improving the development workflow and making a distinction between stable, tested features and untested features. The apricity-core repository has split into three seperate repositories: the standard, unsigned apricity-core repo, a new signed apricity-core repo, and a signed apricity-core-dev repository for developers. All three repos are now being built twice a week. On the github side of things, almost all repositories have moved onto a new branching model. Repositories on this branching model have at least two branches: dev, and master. Feature branches are merged into dev when they are more-or-less finished. Master is considered the stable branch, and dev, as its name suggests, is for development. New features should be built on seperate feature-* branches, releases will be developed on release-* branches, and hotfixes for production code will be built on hotfix-* branches. Both versions of stable apricity-core now build packages from the master branches, and apricity-core-dev builds from dev branches. In terms of the OS itself, not much has changed. Many bugs with the installer have been fixed, more mouse/touchpad drivers are being included by default, and many apricity-* packages have received bugfixes. Autologin for the Gnome edition has been fixed. A particularly annoying bug where the Apricity Icons iconset threw warnings about missing size fields has (finally) been fixed. As an aside, Apricity recently passed 100,000 downloads! Thanks to everyone who helped us reach this milestone.

As always, we hope you will find this release easy and enjoyable to use.

Sincerely,

The Apricity OS Team
